Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Comets and the History of Volatile Matter During Planetary System Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Comets are early Solar System objects, mostly unchanged from the time the Solar System was created. The orbits of comets trace them to the locations in the outer Solar System where they formed. The compositions of molecules released from a comet can be measured by looking at their spectral signals. Combining these compositions with the comet orbits allows scientists to learn what materials were present at different locations in the early Solar System. The investigators will measure the amounts of many molecules in comet spectra, including H2O, HDO, CH4, C2H2, C2H6, H2S, SO2, OCS, CO, H2CO, CH3OH, HCOOH, HCN, HNC, CH3CN, HC3N, NH2CHO, and NH3. They will use ground-based observatories such as the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility, the W. M. Keck Observatory, and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array. The years of 2017-2019 provide an excellent opportunity to study Jupiter Family Comets - comets with smaller orbits for which little is known about their compositions. This research serves the national interest by advancing our knowledge of the materials that served as the building blocks of our Solar System. Shows at the Watson-King Planetarium, Towson University, and the University of Missouri, Saint Louis' new planetarium will feature this research. Students from St. Louis and Baltimore, including many minority students, will have the chance to see them.


The Principal Investigators will use high-resolution molecular spectroscopy of comets to measure the compositions of volatiles released from their nuclei, and to test theories about the early formation of the Solar System. While the orbits of observed comets link them to their dynamical reservoir (the distant Oort cloud or closer Kuiper belt), the suite of detected molecules for an individual comet provides a "snapshot" of the volatile inventory at their location in the protoplanetary disk where these comets formed. The investigators will use ground-based near-infrared and radio observatories, including the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility, the W. M. Keck Observatory, and the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array. By combining the advantages of each wavelength domain, the investigators' goal is to measure the relative abundances among various molecular species, including H2O, HDO, CH4, C2H2, C2H6, H2S, SO2, OCS, CO, H2CO, CH3OH, HCOOH, HCN, HNC, CH3CN, HC3N, NH2CHO, and NH3. New observations are planned of Jupiter Family comets and Oort cloud comets. The 2017-2019 period brings the best opportunity for many years to study Jupiter Family comets - a dynamical class underrepresented in compositional studies of all parent volatiles. These studies will be integrated into a planetarium program that will be hosted at the Watson-King Planetarium, Towson University, and at the University of Missouri, Saint Louis' new digital planetarium, reaching St. Louis and Baltimore students, including many underrepresented minorities. One investigator will also mentor graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When observing objects on the sky like stars, distant galaxies, planets, asteroids, or comets, astronomers try to understand how these objects change in time, how they formed and evolve. As part of this quest, this grant supported research on comets to better understand the origins and evolution of our solar system and perhaps planetary systems around other stars similar to the Sun. This is because comets are leftovers from the formation of our solar system some 4.5 billion years ago. The solar system has changed significantly since these early times, but comets, while not pristine remnants, still preserve clues about the processes that occurred when planets were forming. These clues can improve our understanding of how prebiotically important molecules - those that are needed for life to eventually form - were distributed when our planetary system was very young.

The Principal Investigator (PI) and his collaborators studied the infrared radiation coming from comets through a technique called spectroscopy, which helps astronomers recognize the composition of ices released from comets as they approach and are heated by the Sun. The brightness of a comet varies substantially. Only during a limited period of time - the "apparition" - these objects can be studied with telescopes. The science team studied thirteen comets, including an extensive observing campaign during the long-anticipated "historic" apparition of comet 46P/Wirtanen, which was followed by both professional and amateur astronomers worldwide. The data collected revealed a suite of molecules, including prebiotically important ones, like formaldehyde (a chemical precursor of sugars), acetylene, and ammonia, while findings were reported in a total of nine refereed journal papers (as of writing this report), and a number of national and international conferences. In addition to infrared astronomy, the PI participated in several studies of comets with radio techniques.

These measurements brought new and important evidence about the composition, physical environments, and possible seasonal effects in Jupiter Family Comets, a major sub-group of comets, which has been under-represented in past studies of parent (originally stored as ices in comets) volatiles. The project also brought knew knowledge about the abundances of some molecules, like carbonyl sulfide, that have been studied in only a few comets in the past. During these investigations, the science team pioneered the use of new-generation instruments for comet science, and in the process, provided ample opportunities for students to gain experience as leaders (Principal Investigators) of observing programs, refereed papers, and conference presentations. Graduate student N. Roth, co-mentored by PI B. Bonev, received his Ph.D. and has accepted a Postdoctoral Fellowship at NASA GSFC. Another graduate student, M. Saki, has submitted his first referred paper.

Because of the critical role of comets in decoding the conditions and processes in the proto-planetary disk from which the solar system formed, the synergy between the broad fields of comet science and astrochemical disk modeling is rapidly increasing, including because of work under this NSF grant. The PI helped organizing and led a worldwide synergistic effort at the International Space Science Institute (Bern, Switzerland), entitled: "From Qualitative to Quantitative: Exploring the Early Solar System by Connecting Comet Composition and Protoplanetary Disk Models". This project has stimulated new modeling efforts and an increased interest in comets among leading disk modelers, which ultimately helps discern what the compositional measurements in comets might tell us about the early solar system.

As a feedback to the public, which funds this research, the Broader Impacts of the grant emphasized assistance to science teachers. At American University PI Bonev developed and taught a professional development course for STEM teachers called "From Shattered Planets to ... Apollo and Rosetta".  This class discussed topics ranging from the birth of our solar system and the formation of the Moon to comets and their potential impact on the origin of life on our own planet. The class included highlights from historic space missions: from Apollo's landing, as we approached its 50th anniversary, to the more recent EPOXI and Rosetta missions to comets. Bonev demonstrated the important role of remote sensing astronomy in understanding comet composition and the comets - early solar system connection, thereby disseminating work under current NSF support, and the timely opportunities (recent and future) to explore comets. Thus the class demonstrated the scientific process and hypothesis testing by bringing the ongoing science, as supported by this grant, into the professional development classroom.

Bonev continued his outreach to the Walker-Jones Education Campus at Washington, DC (STEM teacher Mr. Joseph Price), visiting the school for its career day (2019) and advising on lesson planning and curriculum development for middle-school science as needed.
